linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir where the study was conducted is comprised of channel sandstones with interbedded clays of different facies; this is in structural traps, where a high compartmentalization is observed, with proven hydrocarbon accumulations. The study area is located in western Venezuela, Trujillo state, the Ceiba field, as shown in Fig. 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location of the study area, the Ceiba field, Trujillo state, western Venezuela.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of the study area, the Ceiba field, Trujillo state, western Venezuela.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the pores throat profile, capillary pressure curves versus non wetting phase saturation, were graphed, then, capillary pressure correlations were generated in order to find values to the mercury saturations that set the Winland and Pittman models ranging from 10% to 75% as shown in Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Capillary pressure versus saturation mercury. (mercury injection method).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Capillary pressure versus saturation mercury. (mercury injection method).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 3, the graph illustrates one to one of Ri from core and Ri calculated from the multiple linear regression.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: One to one graph of R45 from core and R45 calculated from the multiple linear regression.

formatted-caption.caption-text: One to one graph of R45 from core and R45 calculated from the multiple linear regression.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 4, shows the OOWC located at a depth of 18,510 feet TVDSS in well A.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: OOWC of reservoir A located at a depth of 18,510 feet in the well A.

formatted-caption.caption-text: OOWC of reservoir A located at a depth of 18,510 feet in the well A.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well A has capillary pressure data of cores conducted using the following methods: Porous plate and centrifuge. In Fig. 5, shown the capillary pressure curves.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Capillary pressure Graph (porous plate and centrifuge method) well A.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Capillary pressure Graph (porous plate and centrifuge method) well A.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The average capillary pressure curves for each RT shown in Fig. 6, the same are differentiated through colors codes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Graph average capillary pressure curves RT graph.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graph average capillary pressure curves RT graph.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 7 the graph shows the water saturation in function of J.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Graph water saturation vs J function multiplied for RT.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Graph water saturation vs J function multiplied for RT.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 8, shows a fluid distribution scheme in function of distance starting from free water level (H) in a water-oil system where "H" is defined by equation (12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Scheme fluids distribution based on away from free water level (H).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Scheme fluids distribution based on away from free water level (H).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 9, shows the model results of SWINIT where the initial water saturation of the reservoir "A" is quantified; in wells A and B.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: SWINIT model results in the quantification of initial water saturation of the reservoir A; in wells A and B.

formatted-caption.caption-text: SWINIT model results in the quantification of initial water saturation of the reservoir A; in wells A and B.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 10, the structural map of the study area is presented; it indicates the structural and reservoir fluids limits.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Structural map of the study area with their respective limits of fluids.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural map of the study area with their respective limits of fluids.
